entry.title: DARTSï¼šDifferentiable Architecture Search
entry.content:
æ ‡é¢˜

  • DARTS: Differentiable Architecture Search

æ‘˜è¦

  • This paper addresses the scalability challenge of architecture search by formulating the task in a differentiable manner. Unlike conventional approaches of applying evolution or reinforcement learning over a discrete and non-differentiable search space, our method is based on the continuous relaxation of the architecture representation, allowing efficient search of the architecture using gradient descent. Extensive experiments on CIFAR-10, ImageNet, Penn Treebank and WikiText-2 show that our algorithm excels in discovering high-performance convolutional architectures for image classification and recurrent architectures for language modeling, while being orders of magnitude faster than state-of-the-art non-differentiable techniques. Our implementation has been made publicly available to facilitate further research on efficient architecture search algorithms.

2 ğŸ’¡Note

2.1 è®ºæ–‡è¯•å›¾è§£å†³ä»€ä¹ˆé—®é¢˜ï¼Ÿ

  • Dominant approaches treated the architecture search as a black-box optimization problem over a discrete domain, leading to a large number of architecture evaluation required.
  • Efficient architecture search

2.2 è¿™æ˜¯å¦æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Ÿ

  • Numerous prior studies have explored various approaches based on reinforcement learning (RL), evolution, or Bayesian optimization.
  • But DARTS approaches the problem from a different angle.

2.3 è¿™ç¯‡æ–‡ç« è¦éªŒè¯ä¸€ä¸ªä»€ä¹ˆç§‘å­¦å‡è®¾ï¼Ÿ

Compared with previous methods, differentiable network architecture search based on bilevel optimization is efficient and transferable.

2.4 æœ‰å“ªäº›ç›¸å…³ç ”ç©¶ï¼Ÿå¦‚ä½•å½’ç±»ï¼Ÿè°æ˜¯è¿™ä¸€è¯¾é¢˜åœ¨é¢†åŸŸå†…å€¼å¾—å…³æ³¨çš„ç ”ç©¶å‘˜ï¼Ÿ

  1. non-differentiable search techniques: reinforcement learning (RL), evolution, or Bayesian optimization.
    • Low efficiency
  2. searching architectures within a continuous domain
    • Seek to fine-tune a specific aspect of an architecture, as opposed to learning high-performance architecture building blocks with complex graph topologies with a rich search space.

2.5 ğŸ”´è®ºæ–‡ä¸­æåˆ°çš„è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆä¹‹å…³é”®æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Ÿ

[!Note] An overview of DARTS

(a) Operations on the edges are initially unknown.

(b) Continuous relaxation of the search space by placing a mixture of candidate operations on each edge.

(c) Joint optimization of the mixing probabilities and the network weights by solving a bilevel optimization problem.

(d) Inducing the final architecture from the learned mixing probabilities.

2.5.1 Search Space

Searching for a computation cell as the building block of the final architecture.

  1. A cell is a directed acyclic graph consisting of an ordered sequence of N nodes.
  2. Each node: latent representation
    • â€œLatent representationâ€ refers to a representation form used in machine learning and deep learning to represent hidden features or abstract representations of data.
  3. Each directed edge: operation
  4. Each intermediate node is computed based on all of its predecessors: $$x^{(j)}=\sum_{i<j} o^{(i, j)}\left(x^{(i)} ight)$$
  5. A special zero operation is also included to indicate a lack of connection between two nodes.
  6. learning the cell $ ightarrow$ learning the operations on its edges.

2.5.2 Continuous Relaxation And Optimization

  1. Relaxation: Relax the categorical choice of a particular operation to a softmax over all possible operations: $$ ar{o}^{(i, j)}(x)=\sum_{o \in \mathcal{O}} rac{\exp \left(\alpha_o^{(i, j)} ight)}{\sum_{o^{\prime} \in \mathcal{O}} \exp \left(\alpha_{o^{\prime}}^{(i, j)} ight)} o(x)$$
    • $\alpha_(i, j)$: the operation mixing weights for a pair of nodes $(i, j)$
    • learning a set of continuous variables $Î± = {Î±(i, j)}$
  2. [[Bilevel optimization]]: After relaxation, our goal is to jointly learn the architecture $\alpha$ and the weights $w$ within all the mixed operations $$ egin{array}{cl}\min \alpha & \mathcal{L}{ ext {val }}\left(w^*(\alpha), \alpha ight) \text { s.t. } & w^*(\alpha)=\operatorname{argmin}w \mathcal{L}{ ext {train }}(w, \alpha)\end{array}$$
    • optimize the validation loss, but using gradient descent.
    • the architecture $\alpha$ could be viewed as a special type of hyper-parameter

2.5.3 Approximate Architecture Gradient

  1. One-step Approximation: ï¼ˆAlso can be seen in Nesterovï¼ŒMAMLï¼‰Evaluating the architecture gradient exactly can be prohibitive due to the expensive inner optimization. $$ egin{aligned} & abla_\alpha \mathcal{L}{ ext {val }}\left(w^*(\alpha), \alpha ight) \ \approx & abla_\alpha \mathcal{L}{ ext {val }}\left(w-\xi abla_w \mathcal{L}_{ ext {train }}(w, \alpha), \alpha ight)\end{aligned}$$
  • $\xi$ helps to converge to a better local optimum
  1. Chain rule:
  2. Let: $$ egin{align*}w^\prime=f(w, \alpha) &= w - \xi abla_w \mathcal{L}{ ext{train}}(w, \alpha) \g(w, \alpha) &= \mathcal{L}{ ext{val}}(f(w, \alpha), \alpha)\end{align*}$$
  3. So: $$ egin{align*} abla_\alpha \mathcal{L}{ ext{val}}\left(w-\xi abla_w \mathcal{L}{ ext{train}}(w, \alpha), \alpha ight) &= rac{\partial g}{\partial \alpha} + rac{dg}{d\alpha}\&= rac{\partial g}{\partial f} \cdot rac{\partial f}{\partial \alpha} + rac{dg}{d\alpha}\&= rac{\partial \mathcal{L}{ ext{val}}}{\partial f} \cdot rac{\partial}{\partial \alpha} (w - \xi abla_w \mathcal{L}{ ext{train}}(w, \alpha)) + rac{d\mathcal{L}_ ext{val}}{d\alpha}\end{align*}$$
  4. Where: $$ rac{\partial \mathcal{L}{ ext{val}}}{\partial f} = abla_\alpha \mathcal{L}{v a l}\left(w, \alpha ight)$$
  5. And: $$ rac{\partial}{\partial \alpha} (w - \xi abla_w \mathcal{L}{ ext{train}}(w, \alpha)) = -\xi abla{\alpha, w}^2 \mathcal{L}_{ ext {train }}(w, \alpha)$$
  6. And: $$ rac{dg}{d\alpha} = abla_\alpha \mathcal{L}_{v a l}\left(w^{\prime}, \alpha ight)$$
  7. So: $$ abla_\alpha \mathcal{L}{ ext {val }}\left(w-\xi abla_w \mathcal{L}{ ext {train }}(w, \alpha), \alpha ight)= abla_\alpha \mathcal{L}{ ext {val }}\left(w^{\prime}, \alpha ight)-\xi abla{\alpha, w}^2 \mathcal{L}{ ext {train }}(w, \alpha) abla{w^{\prime}} \mathcal{L}_{ ext {val }}\left(w^{\prime}, \alpha ight)$$
  8. Finite difference approximationï¼šThe expression above contains an expensive matrix-vector product in its second term. $$ abla_{\alpha, w}^2 \mathcal{L}{ ext {train }}(w, \alpha) abla{w^{\prime}} \mathcal{L}{ ext {val }}\left(w^{\prime}, \alpha ight) \approx rac{ abla_\alpha \mathcal{L}{ ext {train }}\left(w^{+}, \alpha ight)- abla_\alpha \mathcal{L}_{ ext {train }}\left(w^{-}, \alpha ight)}{2 \epsilon}$$
  • Central difference: $f^{\prime}(x) \approx rac{f(x+h)-f(x-h)}{2 h}$
  • Taylor Formula:
    1. We have: $f(x)= rac{f\left(x_0 ight)}{0 !}+ rac{f^{\prime}\left(x_0 ight)}{1 !}\left(x-x_0 ight)+\ldots$
    2. Then: $f\left(x_0+h ight)=f\left(x_0 ight)+ rac{f^{\prime}\left(x_0 ight)}{1 !} h+\ldots$
    3. Replace $h$ with $hA$: $ egin{aligned} & f\left(x_0+hA ight)=f\left(x_0 ight)+ rac{f^{\prime}\left(x_0 ight)}{1 !} h A+\ldots \ &f\left(x_0-h A ight)=f\left(x_0 ight)- rac{f^{\prime}\left(x_0 ight)}{1 !} hA+\ldots\end{aligned}$
    4. Subtract one equation from another: $f^{\prime}\left(x_0 ight) \cdot A \approx rac{f\left(x_0+h A ight)-f\left(x_0-h A ight)}{2 h}$
  • Where:
    1. $f^\prime(x_0)= abla_{\alpha, w}^2 \mathcal{L}_{ ext {train }}(w, \alpha)$
    2. $A= abla_{w^{\prime}} \mathcal{L}_{ ext {val }}\left(w^{\prime}, \alpha ight)$
    3. $h=\epsilon$
    4. $w^{ \pm}=w \pm \epsilon abla_{w^{\prime}} \mathcal{L}_{v a l}\left(w^{\prime}, \alpha ight)$
  1. First-order Approximation: $\xi=0$, the second-order derivative will disappear.

2.5.4 Deriving Discrete Architectures

  1. The strength of an operation is defined as $ rac{\exp \left(\alpha_o^{(i, j)} ight)}{\sum_{o^{\prime} \in \mathcal{O}} \exp \left(\alpha_{o^{\prime}}^{(i, j)} ight)}$.
  2. Discretization: At the end of search, a discrete architecture can be obtained by replacing each mixed operation with the most likely operation $$o^{(i, j)}=\operatorname{argmax}_{o \in \mathcal{O}} \alpha_o^{(i, j)}$$
  3. Retain the top-k strongest operations.

2.5.5 Complexity Analysis

2.6 è®ºæ–‡ä¸­çš„å®éªŒæ˜¯å¦‚ä½•è®¾è®¡çš„ï¼Ÿ

2.6.1 Architecture Search

Search for the cell architectures using DARTS, and determine the best cells based on their validation performance

  • operations setsï¼š
    1. Convolutional Cellsï¼ˆOrder: $ReLU-Conv-BN$; N = 7 nodesï¼‰:
      1. 3 Ã— 3 and 5 Ã— 5 separable convolutions
      2. 3 Ã— 3 and 5 Ã— 5 dilated separable convolutions
      3. 3 Ã— 3 max pooling
      4. 3 Ã— 3 average pooling
      5. identity
      6. zero
    2. Recurrent Cellsï¼ˆN = 12 nodesï¼‰:
      1. linear transformations
        1. tanh
        2. relu
        3. sigmoid
      2. identity
      3. zero

2.6.2 Architecture Evaluation

Use these cells to construct larger architectures, which we train from scratch and report their performance on the test set.

  • To evaluate the selected architecture, randomly initialize its weights (weights learned during the search process are discarded), train it from scratch, and report its performance on the test set.

2.6.3 Parameter Analysis

2.6.3.1 Alternative Optimization Strategies

  1. $\alpha$ and $w$ are jointly optimized over the union of the training and validation sets using coordinate descent
    • Even worse than random search
  2. optimize $\alpha$ simultaneously with $w$ (without alteration) using SGD
    • Worse than DARTS

2.6.3.2 Search with Increased Depth

  1. The enlarged discrepancy of the number of channels between architecture search and final evaluation.
  2. Searching with a deeper model might require different hyper-parameters due to the increased number of layers to back-prop through

2.7 è®ºæ–‡ä¸­çš„å®éªŒåŠç»“æœæœ‰æ²¡æœ‰å¾ˆå¥½åœ°æ”¯æŒéœ€è¦éªŒè¯çš„ç§‘å­¦å‡è®¾ï¼Ÿ

  1. Result #1 ï¼š
  2. Result #2 :
    1. CIFAR-10
    2. PTB
  3. Result #3 :Transferability
    1. CIFAR-10 -> ImageNet
    2. PTB -> WT2

2.8 è¿™ç¯‡è®ºæ–‡åˆ°åº•æœ‰ä»€ä¹ˆè´¡çŒ®ï¼Ÿ

  1. A novel algorithm for differentiable network architecture search based on bilevel optimization.
  2. Extensive experiments showing that gradient-based architecture search achieves highly competitive results and remarkable efficiency improvement.
  3. Transferable architectures learned by DARTS.

2.9 ä¸‹ä¸€æ­¥å‘¢ï¼Ÿæœ‰ä»€ä¹ˆå·¥ä½œå¯ä»¥ç»§ç»­æ·±å…¥ï¼Ÿ

  1. Differentiable architecture search on Graph neural networks.
  2. Parallel DARTS
